Name: CHLOROXURON
Description: Chloroxuron is a member of the class of phenylureas that is N,N-dimethylurea in which a hydrogen of the amino group is replaced by a 4-(4-chlorophenoxy)phenyl group. It is a phenylurea herbicide used for the control of annual grasses, mosses and broad-leaved weeds. Common crop plants for which the herbicicide is useful are soy beans, onions, strawberries, and celery. It has a role as a herbicide. It is an aromatic ether, a member of phenylureas and a member of monochlorobenzenes.

environmental_bioconcentrations.References: (1) Yalkowsky SH, Dannenfelser RM; The Aquasol Database of Aqueous Solubility. Fifth Ed, Tucson, AZ: Univ AZ, College of Pharmacy (1992) (2) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods. Washington DC: Amer Chem Soc pp. 5-4, 5-10 (1990) (3) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: An estimated BCF value of 295 was calculated for chloroxuron(SRC), using an experimental water solubility of 3.7 mg/l(1,SRC) and a recommended regression-derived equation(2). According to a classification scheme(3), this BCF value suggests that bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is high, but not very high(SRC).

environmental_biodegradations.References: ROSS JA, TWEEDY BG; SOIL BIOL BIOCHEM 5 (6): 739-46 (1973)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: CHLOROXURON WAS N-DEMETHYLATED BY MICROORGANISMS FROM BOTH LOUISIANA & INDIANA SOILS. METABOLISM WAS PREDOMINANTLY BY DIRECT HYDROLYSIS TO THE ANILINE, WHICH IN TURN UNDERWENT FURTHER TRANSFORMATIONS.

environmental_biodegradations.References: Weed Science Society of America. Herbicide Handbook. 5th ed. Champaign, Illinois: Weed Science Society of America, 1983., p. 100
environmental_biodegradations.Value: BACTERIAL SUSPENSIONS DERIVED FROM HUMUS SOIL METABOLIZE CHLOROXURON TO THE MONOMETHYLATED, DIMETHYLATED, & THE (4-CHLOROPHENOXY)ANILINE DERIVATIVES.

environmental_biodegradations.References: White-Stevens, R. (ed.). Pesticides in the Environment: Volume 3. New York: Marcel Dekker, Inc., 1977., p. 101
environmental_biodegradations.Value: SUBSTITUTED UREAS ARE ALL QUITE STABLE CHEMICALLY & ARE DEGRADED ONLY SLOWLY BY SOIL MICROFLORA, RESULTING IN COMPARATIVELY LONG SOIL HALF-LIFE. /SUBSTITUTED UREAS/

environmental_biodegradations.References: Kirk-Othmer Encyclopedia of Chemical Technology. 3rd ed., Volumes 1-26. New York, NY: John Wiley and Sons, 1978-1984., p. V12 321 (1980)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: Dealkylation is an important pathway of metabolism, and chloroxuron is converted sequentially to the mono- and bis-N-demethylated products in cultured soil bacteria of several crop and weed species.

environmental_biodegradations.References: Hartley, D. and H. Kidd (eds.). The Agrochemicals Handbook. 2nd ed. Lechworth, Herts, England: The Royal Society of Chemistry, 1987., p. A083/Aug 87
environmental_biodegradations.Value: In soil, microbial degradation leads to the monomethylated and demethylated derivatives, and then to the (4-chlorophenoxy)aniline derivative.

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Geissbuhler H et al; Weed Res 3: 277-97 (1963)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: Bacterial suspensions derived from humus soil were demonstrated to metabolize chloroxuron to N-(4-chlorophenoxy)-phenyl-N-methylurea, N-(4-chlorophenoxy)-phenylurea, and (4-chlorophenoxy)-aniline. Upon following the breakdown of chloroxuron as a function of time in two weed species, Polygonum convolvulus was demonstrated to metabolize chloroxuron more rapidly than Galinsoga parviflora. Under aerobic conditions, a soil inoculum at a temperature of 30 °C and an incubation time of 28, 42 and 112 days, biodegradation of chloroxuron was 29, 25, and 29 percent, respectively. In an autoclaved control, 14 percent chloroxuron biodegradation occurred. Under aerobic conditions, a soil inoculum at a temperature of 30 °C and an incubation time of 56 days, biodegradation of chloroxuron was 35 percent. In samples of humus soil and sandy loam, the rate of chloroxuron breakdown was slightly higher in sandy loam (35 percent loss in 8 weeks) than in humus soil (25 percent loss in 8 weeks) under optimal growth conditions. In humus soil, breakdown decreased with time, thereby suggesting that desorption of chloroxuron was too slow to maintain sufficient soil solution concentration. In autoclaved humus soil, breakdown was considerably less pronounced (15 percent loss in 16 weeks) than in non-autoclaved samples(1).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Ross JA, Tweedy BG; Soil Biol Biochem 5: 739-46 (1973)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: Under aerobic conditions, 4 replicate samples of Indiana silt loam soil inoculum, at a temperature of 27 °C and an incubation time of 21 days, biodegradation of chloroxuron was 36, 54, 65, and 80 percent, respectively. Increased degradation in later replicates is unexplained. Under aerobic conditions, 4 replicate samples of Louisiana commerce loam soil inoculum, at a temperature of 27 °C and an incubation time of 21 days, biodegradation of chloroxuron was 18, 54, 65, and 81 percent, respectively. Increased degradation in later replicates is unexplained(1).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Humburg NE; Herbicide Handbook of the Weed Science Society of America. 6th ed (1989)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: Chloroxuron is enzymatically degraded by plants to the monomethylated and demethylated derivatives, followed by decarboxylation of the phenoxyphenylurea to form (4-chlorophenoxy)aniline. The aniline derivative may be formed by direct hydrolysis of chloroxuron. There is no evidence that conjugation of chloroxuron degradation products occur. The rate of breakdown of chloroxuron is slightly higher in sandy loam (35 percent loss in 18 weeks) than in humus soil (25 percent loss) under optimum growth conditions. Chloroxuron applied at 8 pound/acre to a sandy soil caused no phytotoxiciity to cotton, corn or peanuts planted 6 months after application(1).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Hocombe SD et al; Proc 8th Brit Weed Control Conf: Oxford, England 2: 605-13 (1966) (2) Domsch KH, Paul W; Arch Microbiol 97: 283-301 (1974)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: In a turnip bioassay under aerobic conditions and 10 to 25 °C, upon application of 1, 4, and 10 pound/acre chloroxuron, the time for activity to decrease in soil below 50 percent was 4.5 to 25 weeks, 25 to 60 weeks, and 25 to 60 weeks, respectively(1). Chloroxuron was found to have no or insignificant inhibition on the nitrification process on 5 different soil samples(2).

mechanism_of_action.References: Buchel KH (ed); Chemistry of Pesticides p.350 (1983)
mechanism_of_action.Value: Their herbicidal activity depends on inhibition of photosynthesis by blocking of electron transport in Photosystem II. /Ureas/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Hartley, D. and H. Kidd (eds.). The Agrochemicals Handbook. Old Woking, Surrey, United Kingdom: Royal Society of Chemistry/Unwin Brothers Ltd., 1983., p. A083/OCT 83

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: SLIGHTLY TOXIC TO BIRDS, PRACTICALLY NON-TOXIC TO HONEYBEES.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Weed Science Society of America. Herbicide Handbook. 5th ed. Champaign, Illinois: Weed Science Society of America, 1983., p. 100
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: AT 0.4 PPM (2 LB/SURFACE ACRE) IT DOES NOT CAUSE MORTALITY TO FATHEAD MINNOWS TIMEPHALES PROMELAS), & HAD NO EFFECT ON REDUCTION AT 8 WK AFTER APPLICATION.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Worthing, C.R. and S.B. Walker (eds.). The Pesticide Manual - A World Compendium. 8th ed. Thornton Heath, UK: The British Crop Protection Council, 1987., p. 174
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: ... /Slight/ irritant to skin & eyes of rabbits.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: U.S. Department of the Interior, Fish and Wildlife Service. Handbook of Toxicity of Pesticides to Wildlife. Resource Publication 153. Washington, DC: U.S. Government Printing Office, 1984., p. 23
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: SIGNS OF INTOXICATION /IN 3-4 MO OLD FEMALE MALLARD DUCKS/: ATAXIA, WEAKNESS, SIDEWAYS WALKING, FALLING. SIGNS WERE NOT APPARENT UNTIL 3RD DAY AFTER SINGLE ORAL ADMIN /OF CONCN GREATER THAN 2000 MG/KG/, THEN PERSISTED FOR UP TO 14 DAYS. /50% WETTABLE POWDER/
CHLOROXURON WAS TESTED FOR MUTAGENICITY IN THE MITOTIC GENE CONVERSION TEST IN A DIPLOID STRAIN OF SACCHAROMYCES CEREVISIAE. IT WAS NOT ACTIVE AS A MUTAGEN.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: ANDERSEN KJ ET AL; J AGRIC FOOD CHEM 30: 649-56 (1972)
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: CHLOROXURON DID NOT PRODUCE POINT MUTATIONS IN HISTIDINE REQUIRING MUTANTS OF SALMONELLA TYPHIMURIUM.

THE INDUCTION OF HEPATIC MICROSOMAL ENZYMES BY HERBAN, DIURON, CHLOROXURON, & OTHER SUBSTITUTED UREA HERBICIDES WAS INVESTIGATED IN RATS FOLLOWING ORAL ADMIN. HERBAN & DIURON WHEN ADMIN ORALLY FOR 5 DAYS TO ADULT FEMALE RATS OR IN THE DIET TO MALE & FEMALE WEANLING RATS, INCR ACTIVITY OF HEPATIC MICROSOMAL ENZYMES. RESULTS FOR OTHER UREA COMPOUNDS ARE DISCUSSED.

soil_absorption_mobility.References: Weed Science Society of America. Herbicide Handbook. 5th ed. Champaign, Illinois: Weed Science Society of America, 1983., p. 100
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: CHLOROXURON IS QUITE STRONGLY ADSORBED ON SOIL PARTICLES & THIS SEEMS TO BE AN IMPORTANT FACTOR IN CONTROLLING ITS AVAILABILITY IN SOIL SOLN & DETERMINING BOTH THE INITIAL TOXICITY & THE RESIDUAL ACTIVITY IN SOME TYPES OF SOILS. THE FOLLOWING CONCN OF CHLOROXURON ADSORBED WERE IN EQUIL WITH 1 PPM SOIL SOLN: 14 UG/G (SANDY LOAM), 40 UG/G (CLAY LOAM), & 110 UG/G (HUMUS SOIL). WITH SOIL COLUMNS (SANDY, CLAY, & HUMUS SOILS) & SIMULATED RAIN (200 MM IN 45 HR), THE BULK OF CHLOROXURON WAS NOT REMOVED FROM THE TOP 1 CM LAYER OF ALL THREE SOILS. LEACHING DOES NOT APPEAR TO BE A FACTOR IN REMOVING CHLOROXURON FROM THE SURFACE OF SOIL.

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) USDA Pesticide Properties Database; Update May 1995. Available at: https://www.ars.usda.gov/Services/docs.htm?docid=14199 (2) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 23 (1983) (3) Helling CS; Soil Sci Soc Amer, Proc 35: 737-43 (1971) (4) Geissbuhler H et al; Weed Res 3: 277-97 (1963)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: The recommended Koc value for chloroxuron in soil is 2820, with values ranging from 1323 to 6220(1). According to a recommended classification scheme(2), this estimated Koc value suggests that chloroxuron is expected to have slight mobility in soil(SRC). The mobility of chloroxuron in Hagerstown silt clay loam was determined using soil thin layer chromatography. Results showed an Rf value of 0.09, corresponding to a classification of 1, immobile(3). Adsorption of chloroxuron on montmorillonite ranged from 50 to 400 umol/g(4).

plant_translocations.content: The selective action of chloroxuron, a herbicide, was studied on tolerant soybean (Glycine max) and susceptible tall morning glory (Ipomea purpurea) plants. The study investigated the effects of root and foliar applications of chloroxuron on the plants. In the root uptake studies using carbonyl-14C-labeled chloroxuron, it was found that soybean roots absorbed more than 90% of the total radioactivity, while tall morning glory roots absorbed approximately 60% of the total radioactivity. When it came to the distribution of radioactivity in the leaves of the plants, 1, 2, and 3-week-old soybean plants had 0.8%, 3.7%, and 3.5% of the total radioactivity in their leaves, respectively. On the other hand, the leaves of corresponding age in tall morning glory plants contained 29.1%, 33.0%, and 37.4% of the total radioactivity. The metabolism of chloroxuron from root uptake was similar in both species. The identified metabolites were approximately 85% chloroxuron, 13% 3-(p-(p-chlorophenoxy)phenyl-1-methylurea (Compound II), and 2.5% 3-(p-(p-chlorophenoxy)phenylurea (Compound III)) in 3-week-old plants. In a nutrient solution containing 5.6 X M chloroxuron, soybean plants with intact roots were tolerant to the herbicide, while plants with detached roots were susceptible. This indicated that differential translocation, or the movement of the herbicide within the plant, played a crucial role in the selective action of chloroxuron from root uptake. Following foliar spray and washing of 2-week-old plants, tall morning glory foliage absorbed approximately twice as much radioactivity as soybean foliage. Additionally, 18 hours after foliar application, chloroplasts isolated from tall morning glory contained twice as much 14C-chloroxuron as soybean chloroplasts. The concentrations of metabolites recovered from foliar treatment of both species were similar, with approximately 88.1% to 92.2% chloroxuron, 6.4% to 8.6% Compound II, and 0.5% to 1.7% Compound III.
plant_translocations.reference: Feeny, R. W., Parochetti, J. V., & Colby, S. R. (1974). Selective action of chloroxuron on soybean and tall morningglory. Weed science, 22(2), 143-150.

method.Plant Grown Condition: Grown in white quartz sand in 10-cm2, wax-coated cups, watered daily with nutrient solution to 17% moisture (air-dry weight basis) in a greenhouse with natural day length.
method.Chemical Preparation: Carbonyl 14C-chloroxuron (specific activity 1.17 mCi/mM, purity 97.7%) was used, containing two radioactive impurities. The impurities were l,3-di(4-chlorophenylether)urea (Compound V), 1.3%, and 5-(4-chlorodiphenylether)-1,-dimethyl-biuret (Compound IV), 1.0%. The purified 14C-chloroxuron stock solution was dissolved in methanol. Nutrient solutions containing 14C-chloroxuron were prepared by evaporating an aliquot of the methanol stock solution and adding the nutrient solution. A wettable powder formulation consisting of 51.4% 14C-chloroxuron was prepared for foliar applications.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Foliar applications consisted of the 14C-wettable powder supplemented with nonradioactive chloroxuron wettable powder. Foliar applications were made by spraying the herbicide with water as the diluent at a rate of 935 L/ha.
